title: Symptom Diagnostic Guide
description: Troubleshoot your Arco espresso machine with our diagnostic tree. Select your symptom and follow the steps to identify the cause and fix it yourself — or know when to call for professional service.
hero_image_alt: A barista examining the underside of a portafilter with a magnifying glass, diagnostic checklist visible on a tablet beside the machine

symptoms.symptom: No water flows from the group head when brewing

possible_causes.cause: Water reservoir is empty or not seated properly
possible_causes.fix: Refill the reservoir and ensure it clicks into place. Some machines have a float valve — press down on the reservoir firmly.

possible_causes.cause: Grind is too fine — puck is choking the machine
possible_causes.fix: Remove the portafilter. If water flows freely from the group without the portafilter, your grind is too fine. Adjust 2-3 steps coarser.
Backflush with cleaning solution to dissolve coffee oil buildup. If this does not resolve it, the solenoid may need replacement.
Listen for the pump sound when you activate the brew switch. If silent, the pump may have failed or lost electrical connection. Contact Arco service.

possible_causes.cause: Scale blockage in the boiler or thermosyphon tubes (E61 machines)
possible_causes.fix: Perform a full descaling cycle. If severely blocked, a professional chemical flush may be required.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If water does not flow after verifying the reservoir, grind, and performing a backflush and descale.

symptoms.symptom: Espresso is thin, watery, or sour

possible_causes.fix: Grind 1-2 steps finer. The shot should take 25-30 seconds for a 1:2 ratio. If it finishes in under 20 seconds, the grind is far too coarse.
Weigh your dose. A standard double shot uses 16-20g depending on basket size. Increase the dose if under the basket's rated capacity.
Allow the machine to fully heat (PID should read target temp). Flush the group for 3 seconds before pulling the shot. If temperature reads low, the PID may need recalibration.
Check the roast date. Coffee peaks 7-21 days after roasting. Beyond 6 weeks, espresso quality degrades significantly. Use fresh beans.
Use a WDT tool to break up clumps before tamping. Ensure a level tamp. A bottomless portafilter helps diagnose channeling visually.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If adjusting grind, dose, and distribution does not improve the shot, and the machine's temperature and pressure readings are abnormal.

symptoms.symptom: Espresso is harsh, bitter, or astringent

possible_causes.fix: Grind 1-2 steps coarser. If the shot takes longer than 35 seconds, the grind is too fine. Aim for 25-30 seconds.
Check the PID setting. Dark roasts prefer 88-92C; medium roasts 93-96C. Lower the temperature by 1-2 degrees and retest.

possible_causes.cause: Dirty group head — old coffee oils
possible_causes.fix: Backflush with Arco Cleaning Powder. Remove and soak the shower screen. Rancid oils produce a bitter, acrid taste.

possible_causes.cause: Dose is too high — puck is compressed too tightly
possible_causes.fix: Reduce the dose by 1g. An overfilled basket restricts flow and causes over-extraction at the edges.
Dark roasts extract faster. Use a coarser grind, lower temperature (88-91C), and a shorter ratio (1:1.5 to 1:2).

symptoms.when_to_call_service: Bitterness is rarely a machine fault. Exhaust all recipe adjustments first.

symptoms.symptom: Espresso has no crema or very thin crema

possible_causes.cause: Coffee is stale (roasted more than 4-6 weeks ago)
possible_causes.fix: Crema is produced by CO2 trapped in fresh-roasted coffee. Old beans have degassed. Use coffee within 3-4 weeks of roast date.
A finer grind increases extraction and crema production. Adjust finer until the shot takes 25-30 seconds.
Check the pressure gauge during a shot. It should read 8-10 bar. If consistently low, the pump may need servicing or the OPV may need adjustment.
Light roasts naturally produce less crema than medium or dark roasts. This is normal and does not indicate a problem — the flavour may still be excellent.
Allow the machine at least 15-25 minutes to heat fully (longer for E61 and dual boiler machines). Flush the group before pulling.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If pressure is consistently below 8 bar with fresh beans and correct grind.

symptoms.symptom: Steam wand produces weak or wet steam

possible_causes.cause: Machine has not reached full steam pressure
possible_causes.fix: Wait for the steam-ready indicator. Single-boiler machines need to switch modes and heat up — this takes 30-60 seconds after the light activates.

possible_causes.cause: Steam wand tip is blocked with dried milk
possible_causes.fix: Soak the steam tip in hot water with milk-dissolving cleaning solution for 20 minutes. Use a pin to clear each hole. Always wipe and purge after steaming.

possible_causes.cause: Scale buildup in the steam boiler or tube
possible_causes.fix: Perform a full descale. Run solution through the steam circuit specifically.
If steam pressure does not build at all and the boiler is heating (you can hear it), the pressurestat or thermostat may be faulty. Contact service.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If cleaning the tip and descaling does not restore steam power.

symptoms.symptom: Water leaking from the bottom of the machine

possible_causes.cause: Drip tray is full or overflow tube is blocked
possible_causes.fix: Empty the drip tray. Check that the internal overflow drain is not blocked by coffee grounds.

possible_causes.cause: Reservoir is cracked or not seated properly
possible_causes.fix: Remove the reservoir and inspect for cracks. Reseat it firmly. Check the valve seal at the base of the reservoir.

possible_causes.cause: Internal hose connection has come loose
possible_causes.fix: Turn off and unplug the machine. If you are comfortable opening the case, inspect for loose silicone hose connections. Re-clamp if found.

possible_causes.cause: Boiler fitting or seal is leaking
possible_causes.fix: A boiler leak requires professional repair. Do not continue using the machine — turn it off and contact Arco service.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: Immediately if water pools under the machine after checking the drip tray and reservoir.

symptoms.symptom: Water drips from the group head when not brewing

possible_causes.fix: Backflush 10 times with clean water. Coffee particles can prevent the solenoid from closing fully. If persists, the valve may need a rebuild.

possible_causes.cause: E61 group head preinfusion chamber leaking (Maestro)
possible_causes.fix: Disassemble and clean the E61 group. Replace the upper chamber seals if worn.

possible_causes.cause: Expansion valve dripping (normal on some machines)
possible_causes.fix: A slow drip from the expansion valve into the drip tray during heating is normal on some single-boiler machines. This prevents excessive pressure buildup. No action needed.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If dripping is continuous and significant after backflushing.

symptoms.symptom: Water leaks around the portafilter during extraction

possible_causes.fix: Replace the group head gasket. This is the most common cause and an easy DIY fix.
Ensure the portafilter is locked firmly to approximately 90 degrees (6 o'clock position). If it goes past 90, the gasket is compressed — replace it.

possible_causes.cause: Coffee grounds on the gasket seal surface
possible_causes.fix: Wipe the group gasket and the rim of the portafilter before locking in. A single ground can break the seal.

possible_causes.cause: Portafilter ears are worn or damaged
possible_causes.fix: Inspect the portafilter lugs for wear or rounding. If badly worn, replace the portafilter.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: Only if a new gasket and clean portafilter still leak — the group head threads may be damaged.

symptoms.symptom: Machine turns on but does not heat up

possible_causes.cause: Thermal fuse / safety thermostat has tripped
possible_causes.fix: Some machines have a reset button on the back or bottom. Press it. If it trips again immediately, the heating element or thermostat is faulty — call service.
If the machine powers on (lights, pump) but never heats, the element has likely burned out. This requires professional replacement.
If the PID display shows an error code or reads room temperature indefinitely, the PID sensor or controller may be faulty.

possible_causes.cause: Low water level — machine has a low-water safety cutoff
possible_causes.fix: Fill the reservoir. Many machines disable the heater when water is low to prevent element burnout.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If the machine does not heat after filling the reservoir and checking the thermal reset.

symptoms.symptom: Pump is excessively loud, vibrating, or rattling

possible_causes.cause: Air in the pump (common after refilling or descaling)
possible_causes.fix: Open the steam or hot water valve and run the pump for 10 seconds to purge air. Repeat 3 times. The pump should quiet down.
If comfortable opening the case, check that the pump is securely mounted. Tighten any loose screws and ensure the rubber grommets are intact.

possible_causes.cause: Pump is worn and needs replacement
possible_causes.fix: Vibratory pumps have a 3-5 year lifespan. A continuously loud pump that vibrates the machine needs replacement.

possible_causes.cause: Scale restricting water flow through the pump
possible_causes.fix: Descale the machine. Restricted flow causes the pump to work harder and louder.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If purging air and descaling do not reduce the noise.

symptoms.symptom: Grinder motor runs but beans are not grinding

possible_causes.fix: Some hoppers have a sliding gate for removing the hopper without spilling beans. Ensure it is open.

possible_causes.cause: Beans are bridging above the burrs
possible_causes.fix: Oily dark roasts can stick together and create an arch above the burrs. Give the hopper a gentle shake or stir the beans with a spoon.
Severely worn burrs cannot bite into beans. Replace the burr set.

possible_causes.cause: Foreign object jammed in the burrs (stone, twig)
possible_causes.fix: Turn off and unplug the grinder. Remove the hopper and upper burr. Inspect for foreign objects and remove.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If the motor runs but produces a grinding/clicking noise, stop immediately and contact service — a jammed motor can burn out.

symptoms.symptom: Grind size is inconsistent — mix of fine and coarse particles

possible_causes.fix: Inspect the burrs for visible wear (rounded edges, chips). Replace if past their rated lifespan.
After a burr replacement, misalignment causes uneven grinding. Re-align using the manufacturer's procedure or an alignment tool.

possible_causes.cause: Grinder retention causing stale grounds to mix with fresh
possible_causes.fix: Purge 2-3g of coffee before each dose to clear retained grounds from the previous session. Single-dose with a bellows if your grinder supports it.

possible_causes.cause: Beans are a mix of roast levels or origins (unintentional blend)
possible_causes.fix: Check your bean supply. Different densities grind differently. Use a single origin or intentional blend for consistent results.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If burr replacement and alignment do not resolve the inconsistency.

symptoms.symptom: Machine trips the electrical circuit breaker

possible_causes.cause: Circuit is overloaded — other high-draw appliances on the same circuit
possible_causes.fix: Espresso machines draw 1200-1800W. Do not run the machine on the same circuit as a kettle, toaster, or microwave. Move to a dedicated circuit.

possible_causes.cause: Heating element has a ground fault
possible_causes.fix: A failed heating element can short to the chassis. Do not continue using the machine. Contact Arco service immediately.

possible_causes.cause: Power cord or plug is damaged
possible_causes.fix: Inspect the cord for fraying, cuts, or burn marks on the plug. Replace if damaged.
Stop using the machine and contact Arco service.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: Immediately. Repeated breaker trips indicate a potential electrical hazard.

symptoms.symptom: Machine displays an error code

possible_causes.cause: E01/E1 — Water reservoir empty or not detected
possible_causes.fix: Fill and reseat the reservoir. Clean the reservoir contacts with a dry cloth.
Remove, rinse, and re-insert the brew unit until it clicks. Ensure the machine is off during reinsertion.
Perform a full descaling cycle. The machine will not allow brewing until descaling is completed.
Empty the grounds container, rinse, and reinsert.
Try turning the machine off, waiting 30 seconds, and restarting. If the error persists, the sensor needs professional replacement.
Check for kinks in the water supply line (plumbed machines). For tank machines, ensure the reservoir is full. If error persists, the pump may need service.
Turn off, remove hopper, check for foreign objects in the grinder throat. If clear, the motor or control board may be faulty.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: For E05, E06, E07 if the basic troubleshooting steps do not clear the code.

symptoms.symptom: Espresso sprays sideways or has uneven flow from a bottomless portafilter

possible_causes.cause: Uneven coffee distribution in the basket
possible_causes.fix: Use a WDT tool (fine needle tool) to stir and distribute the grounds evenly before tamping. This is the single most effective fix for channeling.
Ensure you tamp level. A calibrated tamper or leveling tool helps. Press straight down — do not twist or angle.

possible_causes.cause: Grind is too fine, creating excessive pressure that finds weak spots
possible_causes.fix: Go 1 step coarser. Extremely fine grinds are more prone to channeling because any tiny imperfection in the puck becomes a path of least resistance.

possible_causes.cause: Shower screen is dirty or damaged, creating uneven water delivery
possible_causes.fix: Remove and clean or replace the shower screen. A blocked screen pushes water through unevenly.
Soak the basket in Arco Cleaning Powder solution for 30 minutes. Use a pin to clear any remaining blocked holes.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: Channeling is almost always a technique or maintenance issue, not a machine fault.

symptoms.symptom: Milk does not froth or produces large bubbles only

possible_causes.cause: Steam pressure too low — machine not fully heated
possible_causes.fix: Wait for full steam readiness. Purge the wand for 2 seconds before submerging to clear condensation.
Use refrigerator-cold milk (4C or below). Pour into a cold stainless steel pitcher. Cold milk gives you more time to create microfoam before it overheats.

possible_causes.cause: Steam tip is at the wrong depth
possible_causes.fix: Position the steam tip just below the surface to introduce air (you should hear a gentle chirping sound). Once you have enough foam, lower the tip deeper to heat and spin the milk.

possible_causes.cause: Steam wand tip holes are blocked
possible_causes.fix: Clean the tip holes with a pin. Soak in milk-cleaning solution.

possible_causes.cause: Using non-dairy milk that does not froth well
possible_causes.fix: Oat milk (barista versions) and soy milk froth best among non-dairy options. Almond and coconut milk are difficult to froth. Look for barista-edition non-dairy milks with added fats and proteins.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: Not typically a service issue unless steam pressure is consistently weak after cleaning and descaling.

symptoms.symptom: Machine takes much longer than usual to heat up

possible_causes.cause: Heavy scale buildup insulating the heating element
possible_causes.fix: Perform a thorough descaling cycle. Scale acts as an insulator, forcing the element to work harder and longer.
In cold environments, machines take longer to heat. This is normal in winter. Allow extra time.
An element can fail partially — still heating, but at reduced power. If descaling does not improve heat-up time, contact service.
If your home has voltage drops (lights dim when the machine heats), the machine receives less power. Try a different circuit or consult an electrician.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If heat-up time has increased by more than 50% and descaling does not help.

symptoms.symptom: Pressure gauge reads above 10 bar during extraction

possible_causes.fix: Grind coarser. Excessive pressure means the water cannot pass through the puck at the correct rate.

possible_causes.cause: Dose is too high for the basket
possible_causes.fix: Reduce the dose by 1-2g. An overpacked basket creates excessive resistance.
The OPV should be set to 10-11 bar (static, no coffee). Adjustment requires opening the machine and turning the OPV screw. Consult the service manual or a technician.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If pressure reads above 11 bar with a normal grind and dose, the OPV may be set too high.

symptoms.symptom: Pressure gauge reads below 7 bar during extraction

possible_causes.fix: Grind finer until the gauge reads 8-10 bar during a standard extraction.
Test with a blind basket — lock in and run the pump. The gauge should climb to 10-11 bar. If it does not, the pump needs servicing.
OPV set below 9 bar will limit maximum extraction pressure. Requires internal adjustment.

possible_causes.cause: Scale restricting flow to the group head
possible_causes.fix: Descale thoroughly. Scale in the lines between the pump and group head reduces effective pressure at the puck.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If blind basket test shows pressure below 9 bar, the pump or OPV needs professional attention.

symptoms.symptom: Coffee has a strange or off taste (chemical, metallic, rubbery)

possible_causes.fix: Run 2-3 full tanks of fresh water through the machine (group and steam circuits). Discard the first several drinks after descaling.

possible_causes.cause: New gasket or silicone parts outgassing
possible_causes.fix: New rubber parts can impart a slight taste for the first 20-30 shots. This is normal and fades quickly. Pull and discard shots until the taste clears.
If the machine has not been used for several days, flush the boiler by running 300-500ml through the group and steam wand before making drinks.
Clean the reservoir with warm water (no soap). Soap residue can cause off-flavours. If the reservoir is discoloured or has biofilm, replace it.

possible_causes.cause: Old coffee oils in the brew path
possible_causes.fix: Backflush with Arco Cleaning Powder. Soak all removable parts. Rancid coffee oils produce a sharp, acrid off-taste.

symptoms.when_to_call_service: If off-taste persists after thorough cleaning, descaling, and flushing with fresh water.

seo.title: Espresso Machine Troubleshooting Guide | Symptom Diagnostics | Arco
seo.meta_description: Diagnose and fix common espresso machine problems with our symptom-based troubleshooting guide. 20+ symptoms with causes, DIY fixes, and when to call for service.
